label: üîì Self Efficacy
description: If you feel confident in yourself to make dietary changes, you are also more likely to shift toward sustainable eating habits.
hover description: Self Efficacy refers to an individual's belief in their ability to successfully adopt and maintain a different diet.

label: üéØ Response Efficacy
description: If you trust that your actions have impact, you are more likely to change your behavior.
hover description: Response Efficacy reflects the belief that adopting a different diet will effectively contribute to positive environmental or health outcomes.

label: ‚ö†Ô∏è Perceived Risks
description: If you perceive greater risks from the environment, you may be more likely to adopt dietary changes.
hover description: Perceived Risks is affected by both the sensitivity towards extreme events but also its frequency.

label: Perceived Risks (No Education)
varname: Climate Risk Perception Rate NoEd Variation

label: Perceived Risks (Primary)
varname: Climate Risk Perception Rate Primary Variation

label: Perceived Risks (Secondary)
varname: Climate Risk Perception Rate Secondary Variation

label: Perceived Risks (Tertiary)
varname: Climate Risk Perception Rate Tertiary Variation

label: üë• Social Norms
description: If sustainable eating is widely accepted among your peers you are also more likely to adopt such diets.
hover description: Social Norms refer to the influence of societal and peer expectations on an individual's diet choices.

label: Conventional Diet Compositions
description: Lorem ipsum lorem ipsum Lorem ipsum lorem ipsum Lorem ipsum lorem ipsum Lorem ipsum lorem ipsum Lorem ipsum lorem ipsum
hover description: This is the assumed diet of the global population that maintains traditional eating habits.

label: Start Year

hover description: This slider controls the start and end year of the food waste scenario, assuming that changes will follow an S-shaped curve.

label: Alternative Diet Compositions
description: Lorem ipsum lorem ipsum Lorem ipsum lorem ipsum Lorem ipsum lorem ipsum Lorem ipsum lorem ipsum Lorem ipsum lorem ipsum
hover description: This is the assumed diet of the global population that deviates from mainstream eating habits, often for health, ethical, or cultural reasons.

label: Start Year

hover description: This slider controls the start and end year of the food waste scenario, assuming that changes will follow an S-shaped curve.

label: by Supply Chain
hover description: Toggle between Food Category and Supply Chain‚Äîonly one can have an impact at a time. The default values display the reference food loss and waste fractions from different sources. Note for the supply chain, a 100% value for each stage accounts for food loss and waste in each food category.

label: Start Year
hover description: This slider controls the start and end year of the food waste scenario, assuming that changes will follow an S-shaped curve.

label: ü•© Pasture Meat
varname: Waste Fraction Scenarios by Food Category[PasMeat]
hover description: Meat from animals raised on grasslands, such as beef and lamb. These meats have a higher environmental impact due to land and water use.

label: üçó Crop Meat
varname: Waste Fraction Scenarios by Food Category[CropMeat]
hover description: Meat from animals primarily fed on crops like soy and corn, including chicken and pork. Generally, they have a lower footprint than pasture meats.

label: ü•õ Dairy
varname: Waste Fraction Scenarios by Food Category[Dairy]
hover description: Products made from milk, such as cheese, yogurt, and butter. Dairy farming contributes to greenhouse gas emissions and water usage.

label: ü•ö Eggs
varname: Waste Fraction Scenarios by Food Category[Eggs]
description: Chicken Eggs, Duck Eggs, Quail Eggs
hover description: A nutrient-rich food source from poultry, including chicken, duck, and quail eggs. Lower environmental impact compared to meat but still requires feed and water.

label: üå± Pulses
varname: Waste Fraction Scenarios by Food Category[Pulses]
description: Lentils, Chickpeas, Black Beans, Kidney Beans, Peas
hover description: Protein-rich plant foods like lentils, beans, and chickpeas. They improve soil health and have a low carbon footprint.

label: üåæ Grains
varname: Waste Fraction Scenarios by Food Category[Grains]
description: Wheat, Rice, Corn, Oats, Barley, Quinoa
hover description: Staple crops such as wheat, rice, corn, and oats. Widely consumed and essential for global food security, but some require high water usage.

label: üçéü•¶ Vegetables and Fruits
varname: Waste Fraction Scenarios by Food Category[VegFruits]
description: Carrots, Potatoes, Apples, Bananas, Tomatoes, Spinach
hover description: A diverse group including leafy greens, root vegetables, and berries. Generally have a lower environmental impact, but factors like transport and refrigeration matter.

label: üåø Other Crops
varname: Waste Fraction Scenarios by Food Category[OtherCrops]
hover description: Includes foods like nuts, sugar, coffee, and oils (palm, soybean, canola). Some have significant land-use impacts, especially tropical crops like palm oil.

label: üöú Primary Production
hover description: Losses occurring at the farm level due to unharvested crops, pest damage, extreme weather, or overproduction that leads to surplus food being discarded before it enters the supply chain.

label: üì¶ Post Harvest
hover description: Losses happening after harvest but before processing or distribution, often due to inadequate storage, transportation issues, spoilage, or inefficiencies in handling and drying.

label: üè≠ Processing
description: Food Manufacturers, Factories, Butchers, Millers, Packaging Companies
hover description: Losses during food manufacturing, including edible portions discarded during trimming, inefficiencies in processing, and overproduction leading to disposal before reaching consumers.

label: üöö Distribution
description: Wholesalers, Retailers, Supermarkets, Delivery Services, Restaurants
hover description: Waste occurring at the wholesale, retail, and food service levels due to packaging damage, expired goods, improper handling, or rejection of products based on aesthetic standards.

label: üçΩÔ∏è Consumption
description: Households, Consumers, Restaurants, Cafeterias, Food Banks
hover description: Waste generated at the consumer level, including uneaten leftovers, spoiled groceries, and plate waste in households, restaurants, and cafeterias
